name: Ownit
details: The first four months here I worked on a solo project which I had full ownership of and had to collaborate with stakeholders to develop requirements. The project was a serverless media management and optimization tool which allowed the product merchandising team to optimize images and videos for high-performance product landing pages. It was challenging since the backend were built on AWS (Lambda, S3, API Gateway) and I had no prior AWS experience. The backend part of the project was also built on AWS Serverless Application Model (SAM). I also built a frontend in React.js and embed it into an existing portal used internally by Ownit. Finally, I also maintained documentation throughout the process of building the project which includes design decisions, user flow diagram, etc.

The latter half of the internship I worked alongside of ex-Amazon engineers to develop a merchandising portal deployed on AWS, which was a lot closer to what a day-to-day of a software engineer looks like. I left the internship learning the startup world and the importance (and joy) of documentation.

name: PCL Constructions
details: I got to work on several different apps across PCl's Job Site Suite, their job site management solution. I jumped between apps and took on tasks/features that required full-stack knowledge, it was also my first time using Angular.js ever so it was good learn another frontend framework. What I learned the most during my time here is defintely the backend side of things, which I was the area I was lacking the most coming in. Working on systems built on a monolithic and microservice architecture respectively, I got learn the differences between them. I even got to build a reporting microservice using gRPC from start to the finish myself, including designing the data model

Beyond coding, I also wrote a comprehensive developer's onboarding documentation containing development process, terminology definitions, local development setup, etc. I wrote this mainly for myself since I'm really good at forgetting stuff. I also learned the difference between how a large-sized company operates compared to a startup.
